original: THE TALE OF JEMIMA PUDDLE-DUCK
BEATRIX POTTER (public domain)
https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Tale_of_Jemima_Puddle-Duck
This will be a block-by-block translation
no
Jemima Puddle-duck (bird)
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken

original: Mrs. Rebeccah Puddle-duck (bird)
jan Ke Tami: waso Jalanpa

original: Kep (dog)
jan Ke Tami: soweli Tenpona

original: THE TALE OF JEMIMA PUDDLE-DUCK
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken

original: WHAT a funny sight it is to see a brood of ducklings with a hen!
jan Ke Tami: a, sina lukin e waso lili mute lon waso mama ona la, ni li musi tawa lukin!

original: —Listen to the story of Jemima Puddle-duck, who was annoyed because the farmer's wife would not let her hatch her own eggs.
jan Ke Tami: —o kute e toki pi waso Jonken. ona li pilin pona ala tan ni: ona li ken ala mama pali e sike waso ona tan wile pi jan pali soweli ona, li ken mama awen taso e sike waso pi waso ante.

original: HER sister-in-law, Mrs. Rebeccah Puddle-duck, was perfectly willing to leave the hatching to some one else—"I have not the patience to sit on a nest for twenty-eight days; and no more have you, Jemima. You would let them go cold; you know you would!"
jan Ke Tami: waso sama ona pi kulupu ante li waso Jalanpa. waso ante li mama awen e sike ona la, ni li pona lon tenpo ale—"mi wile ala awen lon supa mama lon tenpo mun wan a; waso Jonken o, sina pilin sama a. sike li kama lete tan weka sina; sina sona e ni!"

original: I wish to hatch my own eggs; I will hatch them all by myself, quacked Jemima Puddle-duck.
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonke li mu: "mi wile mama e sike mi e sike pi waso ante ala; mi taso a li kama mama e ona."

original: SHE tried to hide her eggs; but they were always found and carried off.
jan Ke Tami: ona li len e sike ona; taso tenpo ale la, jan li kama lukin e sike, li weka e sike.

original: Jemima Puddle-duck became quite desperate. She determined to make a nest right away from the farm.
jan Ke Tami: wile pi waso Jonken li kama wawa mute. ona li wile pali e supa mama lon weka tomo lon tenpo ni a.

original: SHE set off on a fine spring afternoon along the cart-road that leads over the hill.
jan Ke Tami: tenpo suno pona wan li open la, ona li tawa lon poka nasin tawa nena.

original: She was wearing a shawl and a poke bonnet.
jan Ke Tami: ona li jo e len lawa e len awen kin.

original: WHEN she reached the top of the hill, she saw a wood in the distance.
jan Ke Tami: ona li kama lon sewi nena la, ona li lukin e ma pi kasi suli.

original: She thought that it looked a safe quiet spot.
jan Ke Tami: lukin ona la, ni li ma pona, li ken ala ike e ona.

original: JEMIMA PUDDLE-DUCK was not much in the habit of flying. She ran downhill a few yards flapping her shawl, and then she jumped off into the air.
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken li tawa pi mute ala lon kon. ona li tawa wawa kepeken noka ona, li tawa e luka ona, li tawa sewi.

original: SHE flew beautifully when she had got a good start.
jan Ke Tami: open pona la ona li ken tawa pona lon kon.

original: She skimmed along over the tree-tops until she saw an open place in the middle of the wood, where the trees and brushwood had been cleared.
jan Ke Tami: ona li awen tawa lon sewi lili kasi la, ona li kama lukin e ma lili pona pi kasi suli ala.

original: JEMIMA alighted rather heavily, and began to waddle about in search of a convenient dry nesting place. She rather fancied a tree-stump amongst some tall fox-gloves.
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken li pilin pona tan ni, li tawa lon ma, li wile lukin e supa pona tawa mama. ona li lukin e kiwen suli tan kasi suli la ni li pona tawa ona.

original: But—seated upon the stump, she was startled to find an elegantly dressed gentleman reading a newspaper.
jan Ke Tami: taso—kiwen kasi ni la, mije li lon, li jo e len pi pona suli, li lukin e lipu pi sona sin.

original: He had black prick ears and sandy coloured whiskers.
jan Ke Tami: kute ona li pimeja, li tawa sewi. sinpin la, kule linja li sama ko ma walo.

original: Quack? said Jemima Puddle-duck, with her head and her bonnet on one side—"Quack?"
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken li toki. "mu?" ona li poka e lawa ona e len lawa ona.—"mu?"

original: THE gentleman raised his eyes above his newspaper and looked curiously at Jemima—
jan Ke Tami: mije pi len pona li sewi e lukin lon selo lipu, li kama lukin e waso Jonken, li lukin sona e ijo—

original: Madam, have you lost your way? said he. He had a long bushy tail which he was sitting upon, as the stump was somewhat damp.
jan Ke Tami: "a, sina o, sina sona ala e nasin pona sina anu seme?" monsi ona la, linja mute li lon palisa. telo lili li lon kiwen la, mije li lape e monsi ona lon ala kiwen, li lape lon palisa.

original: Jemima thought him mighty civil and handsome. She explained that she had not lost her way, but that she was trying to find a convenient dry nesting-place.
jan Ke Tami: lukin la, ona li pona tawa waso Jonken. "ala a. mi sona e nasin mi. mi wile e supa mama pona lon ala telo."

original: AH! is that so? indeed! said the gentleman with sandy whiskers, looking curiously at Jemima. He folded up the newspaper, and put it in his coat-tail pocket.
jan Ke Tami: mije li toki. "a! ni li lon anu seme! lon, lon!" linja sinpin ona pi kule ma walo la, ona li lukin e waso sama wile sona. ona li lili e lipu ona, li poki e lipu lon insa pi len ona.

original: Jemima complained of the superfluous hen.
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken li toki e pilin ike ona tan mute waso lon tomo ona.

original: Indeed! how interesting! I wish I could meet with that fowl. I would teach it to mind its own business!
jan Ke Tami: "a! musi! mi wile kama sona e waso ni. ken la mi ken nasin pona e ona!

original: BUT as to a nest—there is no difficulty: I have a sackful of feathers in my woodshed. No, my dear madam, you will be in nobody's way. You may sit there as long as you like, said the bushy long-tailed gentleman.
jan Ke Tami: taso sina wile e supa pona la—ni li ike ala: tomo pali lili mi la ko waso pona li lon." mije pi palisa monsi suli pona li toki: "a, o pilin ike ala; sina awen lon ni la, ni li ike ala tawa mi. sina ken awen lon ni lon tenpo pi wile sina."

original: He led the way to a very retired, dismal-looking house amongst the fox-gloves.
jan Ke Tami: ona li nasin e waso tawa tomo. lukin la, tomo li pona ala. kasi mute li lon poka ona.

original: It was built of faggots and turf, and there were two broken pails, one on top of another, by way of a chimney.
jan Ke Tami: tomo li palisa lili kasi, li linja palisa kasi, li ma awen. poki suli pakala tu li lon kin, li lon sewi tomo tawa ken pi kon pimeja.

original: THIS is my summer residence; you would not find my earth—my winter house—so convenient, said the hospitable gentleman.
jan Ke Tami: mije pi pana tomo li toki: "ni li tomo mi tawa tenpo seli; sina tawa tomo lupa mi—tawa tomo mi pi tenpo lete—la, pona ona li sama ala pona pi tomo ni."

original: There was a tumble-down shed at the back of the house, made of old soap-boxes. The gentleman opened the door, and showed Jemima in.
jan Ke Tami: monsi tomo la, tomo lili li lon, li pakala tawa lukin. selo pi tomo lili li kiwen tan poki jo suli. mije li open e lupa, li tawa e waso lon insa.

original: THE shed was almost quite full of feathers—it was almost suffocating; but it was comfortable and very soft.
jan Ke Tami: tomo ni la, len waso suwi mute li lon—mute len li suli a, li kama len e kon; taso ona li pona tawa pilin, li suwi tawa pilin.

original: Jemima Puddle-duck was rather surprised to find such a vast quantity of feathers. But it was very comfortable; and she made a nest without any trouble at all.
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken la, mute pi len ni li nasa lili. taso len li pona a. ni li kama supa mama kepeken pali ala a.

original: WHEN she came out, the sandy whiskered gentleman was sitting on a log reading the newspaper—at least he had it spread out, but he was looking over the top of it.
jan Ke Tami: ona li weka tan tomo la, mije li lon supa li lukin tawa lipu—ona li lukin tawa lipu, taso ona li lukin e ijo ante, li lukin tawa sewi lipu.

original: He was so polite, that he seemed almost sorry to let Jemima go home for the night. He promised to take great care of her nest until she came back again next day.
jan Ke Tami: ona li toki pi suwi mute. kute la, ona li pilin pakala tan ni: waso Jonken li tawa tomo tan tenpo pimeja kama. toki mije la, mije li awen pona e supa mama waso tawa tenpo suno kama tan kama waso.

original: He said he loved eggs and ducklings; he should be proud to see a fine nestful in his wood-shed.
jan Ke Tami: toki ona la, sike waso en waso lili sin li pona a; ona li ken lukin e ni ale lon tomo ona la, ona li ken kama pilin pona.

original: JEMIMA PUDDLE-DUCK came every afternoon; she laid nine eggs in the nest. They were greeny white and very large. The foxy gentleman admired them immensely. He used to turn them over and count them when Jemima was not there.
jan Ke Tami: tenpo li tawa la, waso Jonken li kama lon tenpo suno ale. ona li pana e sike luka tu tu lon supa. sike li suli. kule ona li walo laso. mije li lukin, li pilin suwi tan ni. waso Jonken li lon ala la, ona li luka e sike, li sona sin e nanpa sike.

original: At last Jemima told him that she intended to begin to sit next day—"and I will bring a bag of corn with me, so that I need never leave my nest until the eggs are hatched. They might catch cold," said the conscientious Jemima.
jan Ke Tami: pini la, waso Jonken li toki tawa mije: "mi wile awen lon tenpo suno kama. mi kama e poki pan kin la mi ken awen lon tenpo mama ale a. seli awen mi la waso sin li ken kama tan sike. mi wile ala e lete lon sike."

original: MADAM, I beg you not to trouble yourself with a bag; I will provide oats. But before you commence your tedious sitting, I intend to give you a treat. Let us have a dinner-party all to ourselves! May I ask you to bring up some herbs from the farm-garden to make a savoury omelette? Sage and thyme, and mint and two onions, and some parsley. I will provide lard for the stuff—lard for the omelette, said the hospitable gentleman with sandy whiskers.
jan Ke Tami: mije pi toki suwi li toki: "waso pona o kama ala e poki sina; mi o kama e moku. sina kama awen tan mama lon tenpo kama lili la mi wile pana e moku pona tawa mi tu. mi o moku suli! sina ken ala ken kama e kasi namako tan tomo ma sina? ni li ken kama e moku pona tan sike. laso namako en kili tu, en namako lipu en kasi kili a. mi jo e ko tawa moku, li pana e ona tawa moku—ni li ko pona tawa moku tan sike."

original: JEMIMA PUDDLE-DUCK was a simpleton: not even the mention of sage and onions made her suspicious.
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken li sona lili. mije li toki e namako e moku kin la, toki li nasa ala tawa kute waso.

original: She went round the farm-garden, nibbling off snippets of all the different sorts of herbs that are used for stuffing roast duck.
jan Ke Tami: ona li tawa ma kili lon poka pi tomo ona, li weka jo e kasi mute. soweli li wile moku e waso la, kasi ni ale li ken namako e waso tawa moku.

original: AND she waddled into the kitchen, and got two onions out of a basket.
jan Ke Tami: ona li tawa tomo moku, li kama jo e kili tu tan poki.

original: The collie-dog Kep met her coming out, "What are you doing with those onions? Where do you go every afternoon by yourself, Jemima Puddle-duck?"
jan Ke Tami: waso li kama weka tan tomo la, soweli awen Tenpona li lukin e kama ona. "tan seme la sina jo e kili ni? sina tawa seme lon tenpo suno ale, waso Jonken o?"

original: Jemima was rather in awe of the collie; she told him the whole story.
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken la soweli awen li pona sewi; waso li toki e ale ona.

original: The collie listened, with his wise head on one side; he grinned when she described the polite gentleman with sandy whiskers.
jan Ke Tami: soweli li kute. lawa ona pi sona pona li anpa lon poka wan. waso li toki e mije pi toki suwi la, sinpin ona li ante tan pilin musi.

original: HE asked several questions about the wood, and about the exact position of the house and shed.
jan Ke Tami: soweli li wile sona e ijo mute pi ma kasi, e nasin tawa tomo mije.

original: Then he went out, and trotted down the village. He went to look for two fox-hound puppies who were out at walk with the butcher.
jan Ke Tami: pini la, ona li tawa, li tawa ma tomo. ona li wile lon poka pi soweli awen ante. soweli ante en jan ona pi pali moku soweli li lon poka.

original: JEMIMA PUDDLE-DUCK went up the cart-road for the last time, on a sunny afternoon. She was rather burdened with bunches of herbs and two onions in a bag.
jan Ke Tami: waso Jonken li tawa lon poka nasin lon tenpo pi sona pona. ni li tenpo pini tawa ni. ona li jo e mute, e kasi mute, e poki pi kili tu la, ni li mute tawa ona.

original: She flew over the wood, and alighted opposite the house of the bushy long-tailed gentleman.
jan Ke Tami: ona li tawa lon sewi kon, li tawa lon sewi kasi, li kama lon ma lon poka tomo lon mije pi palisa monsi linja suli.

original: HE was sitting on a log; he sniffed the air, and kept glancing uneasily round the wood. When Jemima alighted he quite jumped.
jan Ke Tami: ona li awen lon kiwen. ona li pilin e kon kepeken nena, li lukin tawa ma pi kasi suli tan pilin pi ike kama. waso li kama la, mije li tawa sewi tan wawa pi pilin ni.

original: Come into the house as soon as you have looked at your eggs. Give me the herbs for the omelette. Be sharp!
jan Ke Tami: "o lukin e sike sina. sina pini e lukin la, o kama lon tomo mi. o pana e kasi tawa mi tawa pali pi moku sike. o tawa a!"

original: He was rather abrupt. Jemima Puddle-duck had never heard him speak like that.
jan Ke Tami: ona li toki wile wawa. waso Jonken la, ona li toki ni ala lon tenpo ante.

original: She felt surprised, and uncomfortable.
jan Ke Tami: ni li nasa e pilin ona, li ike e pilin ona.

original: WHILE she was inside she heard pattering feet round the back of the shed. Some one with a black nose sniffed at the bottom of the door, and then locked it.
jan Ke Tami: ona li lon insa tomo la, ona li kute e kalama noka tan monsi tomo. jan li pilin e kon kepeken nena pimeja lon lupa, li pini awen e lupa.

original: Jemima became much alarmed.
jan Ke Tami: pilin ike pil waso Jonken li kama suli a.

original: AMOMENT afterwards there were most awful noises—barking, baying, growls and howls, squealing and groans.
jan Ke Tami: tenpo lili la, kalama ike mute li lon—mu soweli en mu utala en mu wawa en mu anpa en mu ike.

original: And nothing more was ever seen of that foxy-whiskered gentleman.
PRESENTLY Kep opened the door of the shed, and let out Jemima Puddle-duck.
Unfortunately the puppies rushed in and gobbled up all the eggs before he could stop them.
He had a bite on his ear and both of the puppies were limping.
JEMIMA PUDDLE-DUCK was escorted home in tears on account of those eggs.
SHE laid some more in June, and she was permitted to keep them herself: but only four of them hatched.
Jemima Puddle-duck said that it was because of her nerves; but she had always been a bad sitter.
